Hall and Miller to Propose
Housing for Undergraduates
BY ROBERT INSOFT
Due to the increasing need
,for undergraduate housing at
Hopkins, the administration is
considering the construction of
an additional 400 living units
adjacent to the existing dormitory complex on the northern
side of campus.
According to Bettye Miller,
the University's Director of
Auxiliary Enterprises, a study
analyzing the project's design
and cost has been underway
for some time. The present plan
calls for four buildings, to house
undergraduates only.
The first two would be built
in the wooded area between the
Brown Infirmary and the baseball diamond. The remaining
two structures are tentatively
planned for tennis court area,
parallel to Charles St. and
abutting the back of the existing
"New Dorms". A new site for
the tennis courts has not yet
been decided upon.
Although the final designs
are incomplete, preliminary
sketches show the units to

consist of 3-5 bedrooms, a living
room, and kitchenette. The
project would also include a
new, larger food service area and
dining hall for freshmen and 400
additional students, a conference
and recreation room and a small
movie theatre, according to
Jakie Hall, Dean of Academic
Services and coordinator of the
housing study.
"We are at the point of
bringing facts and figures together," Miller explained. "What

is needed now.is Dr. Muller's and
the Board of Trustees' approval." • At present, the Trustees'

BY SUNITA HANJURA
Eight of the ten speakers for
this year's Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium have been confirmed. They will provide several
different viewpoints on this
year's Symposium topic, titled
"The Crisis of the American
Spirit: An Evaluation of Our
Times."
The first lecture of the
series will be presented on

October 6th by Dr. Henry Steele
Commager, a leading American
historian and author of many
books, including The Growth of
the American Republic and
American Heritage.
Commager is one of eight
confirmed speakers so far with
two more to be scheduled
shortly.
His speech, "The
American Spirit: A Historical
Perspective" will deal with the
historical connotations of "the

American spirit" and how it has
been influenced by the Revolution, the Civil War, the Depression, and events since.
On October 15, Dr. Steven
Muller, founder and past chairman of the American Association of Private Universities and
one of the nation's prime
authorities on education, will
examine the quality of today's
education and the relationship
between "private institutions"

and the government in his
lecture "The Educational Crisis:
Is America Flunking Out?"

research psychologist, Dr. Robert Coles will discuss "The

As the date of the constitutional referendum approaches,

exactly what we expect of it.
Without a doubt, there exists

student body: to expound the

which students could exchange
views and reach other students; a
spearhead of student relations
with the faculty and administration; and a platform for expressing student views on current
issues to the outside world.
Unfortunately, our so-called
student council communicates
directly with no one but itself.
When students cannot identify

voters to show our disapproval
and abolish the council as a
whole.

untenable absurdity when it

to come, the welcome chill of fall in Baltimore. Time

12 minutes and 30 seconds more.
"Getting in some reading on your last day?"
The store's truck driver was watching me from the end
of the aisle. "You people think you can just come in
here for a summer job and then leave, go off to some
fancy John Hopkins University." He chuckled, his belly
quivering with the secret knowledge of my future.
"You'll never make it in the real world out there ."
He pointed upwards at the pipe-tangled ceiling. "You'll

job." He walked away, leaving me the stunned recipient
of his wisdom. I had thought the Strand was the real
world.
The Lure of the Strand
Before you read any more of this article, spread
200 copies of the News-Letter, open to the fold, across
your living room floor. Imagine for a moment that
every letter of every linee is the spine of a book and that
your eyes are traveling across shelf after shelf of these
books. When your eyes have moved across every line of
all 200 copies of this article, you will have looked at as
many letters as there are books at the Strand Book
Store. In fact, if you lined up every book side by side,
the row would stretch from the World Trade Center to
the doorstep of Harlem. This makes the Strand probably the largest used book store in the world. There are
some people working there who know every book.
The Strand sits on the dingy, well-trafficked
corner of 12th and Broadway, and looks from the
outside as if it could hold barely one tenth its number of
books. The store is about fifty years old. It was named
after the Strand in London, a street which has historically been a marketplace for used and rare b000ks. New
York's Strand was originally one of a number of such
stores in the area (Abbey Books, 8th Street Bookstore),
most of which are now out of businesss. The Strand
has expanded and thrived partly because of its collection
of reviewer's copies of new books sold for half of list
price and its international mail order service (free
shipping to anywhere in the world).
To my friends and me, as we contemplated a
summer in Greenwich Village, it seemed a stimulating
place to work. After all, didn't we all love books?
And didn't the Strand's bustling main floor
with its creaking floors, its whirring fans, and its tweedy
customers evoke the browser's dream of a 19th century
bookstore? There is always a bag lady or two sorting
thhrough the paperbaacks, and the employees are figures

Cleaver.

of my time at the Strand stand out: the friends I made,

wasn't the boredom of doing nothing (which isn't really

Jay Gridders Offto Slow Start Against Division Champs
BY A.J. JOHNSON
The Blue Jay football
season got off to a rocky start
last Saturday as the division
champion Widener Pioneers
defeated Johns Hopkins 48-7.
A combination of powerful
Pioneer running and well-executed fakes and hand-offs
helped Widener to penetrate
the Jay defense repeatedly,
while Hopkins ball carriers
could hardly break through the
Widener line. Hopkins, unable
to coordinate its passing
attempts for most of the game,
relied heavily on a running
attack which proved unsuccessful against the Pioneers.

Hal Johnson of Widener
scored a touchdown on the
first Pioneer possession of the
game wiien he cruised through
a hole in the Hopkins line. On
the next Hopkins possession,
Bruce Kane fumbled the ball
on the Hopkins 25-yard line,
and Widener recovered,scoring
the second Pioneer touchdown
a few plays later.
Hopkins quarterback Jim
Margraff was usually unable to
complete passes to either Bill
Stromberg or wide receiver
John Potthast. In the secon
quarter, a toss intended for
Stromberg was intercepted by
Widener safety Tom Deary,
setting the stage for the third

Pioneer touchdown. A long
drive downfield later in the
second quarter gave Widener its
fourth
touchdown.
At
halftime, the score stood at
28-0 in favor of the Pioneers.
After the half, the Jays
attacked with more force. A
drive early in the third quarter
put them in scoring position
until a clipping penalty killed
the opportunity. Hopkins had
to punt again, and Widener
scored another touchdown on
the possession. The Pioneers
then got in another punch as
Hal Johnson scored his second
goal of the game, raising the
score to 41-0.
In the fourth quarter, the

Jays put their only tally on the
board. Mike Miller intercepted
a Widener pass at the Hopkins
41-yard line and the Jays
moved the ball downfield. Jim
Margraff, injured in the third
quarter, was replaced by
freshman quarterback John
Bevilacqua, who gave an impressive debut performance.
Bevilacqua completed passes to
both Stromberg and tight end
Randy Scholl for the only
fruitful Jay attack.
The
Hopkins touchdown was scored on a pass caught by
Potthast.
The Jays threatened again
in the final minutes of the
fourth quarter, bringing the

ball to a first-and-goal with
fifteen seconds remaining in
the game. Widener held tight,
though, and Hopkins was prevented from scoring as the
clock ran out.
Despite their lackluster
performance against the Pioneers, the Jays could not count
the game as a total loss.
Widener dominates Division Ill
football play year after year,
almost the same way Hopkins
dominates in Lacrosse. While
starting out the season against
the toughest opponent may be
demoralizing, it also helps
point out early season mistakes
in time to correct them.

issues to the outside world.

It was my last day of work in the underground
of the Strand Book Store, at the steamy navel of New
York City. I was speed-reading the flap of one of the
books as I shelved it. 6:02; 13 minutes to go. Then I
would emerge for the last time into the cool of a 98
degree dusk. Washing away the last of the book dust at
the basin upstairs would be a spiritual rebirth, a shedding
of skin. I dwelled in a reverie of the joyful schooll days
to come, the welcome chill of fall in Baltimore. Time
would begin to count itself in hours instead of minutes.
12 minutes and 30 seconds more.
"Getting in some reading on your last day?"
The store's truck driver was watching me from the end
of the aisle. "You people think you can just come in
here for a summer job and then leave, go off to some
fancy John Hopkins University." He chuckled, his belly
quivering with the secret knowledge of my future.
"You'll never make it in the real world out there ."
He pointed upwards at the pipe-tangled ceiling. "You'll
be back in a year, hungry with hat in hand, begging a
job." He walked away, leaving me the stunned recipient
of his wisdom. I had thought the Strand was the real
world.
The Lure of the Strand
Before you read any more of this article, spread
200 copies of the News-Letter, open to the fold, across
your living room floor. Imagine for a moment that
every letter of every linee is the spine of a book and that
your eyes are traveling across shelf after shelf of these
books. When your eyes have moved across every line of
all 200 copies of this article, you will have looked at as
many letters as there are books at the Strand Book
Store. In fact, if you lined up every book side by side,
the row would stretch from the World Trade Center to
the doorstep of Harlem. This makes the Strand probably the largest used book store in the world. There are
some people working there who know every book.
The Strand sits on the dingy, well-trafficked
corner of 12th and Broadway, and looks from the
outside as if it could hold barely one tenth its number of
books. The store is about fifty years old. It was named
after the Strand in London, a street which has historically been a marketplace for used and rare b000ks. New
York's Strand was originally one of a number of such
stores in the area (Abbey Books, 8th Street Bookstore),
most of which are now out of businesss. The Strand
has expanded and thrived partly because of its collection
of reviewer's copies of new books sold for half of list
price and its international mail order service (free
shipping to anywhere in the world).
To my friends and me, as we contemplated a
summer in Greenwich Village, it seemed a stimulating
place to work. After all, didn't we all love books?
And didn't the Strand's bustling main floor
with its creaking floors, its whirring fans, and its tweedy
customers evoke the browser's dream of a 19th century
bookstore? There is always a bag lady or two sorting
thhrough the paperbaacks, and the employees are figures
resembling, among others, Vincent Van Gogh and Wally
Cleaver.
For almost all the employees, the Strand is a way
of making money rather than a career. Most of them are

aitists who work at the store because ideally it's a job
that doesn.'t distract them or fatigue them from their
real work. At the Strand, you may find a truck driver
who is awell respected sculptor, a playwright shelving a
paperback copy of his own play, or a punk keyboardist
typing up a book order slip. In many ways the Strand
has been the cradle of punk; Patty Smith, Richard Hell,
Robin Crutchfield' (DNA, Dark Day), and Jody Harris
(Contortions, Ray Beats) once worked or are still
working there. To get an idea of the kind of people who
shop at the Strand,leaf through a copy of Self-Portraits,
by former Strand employee Burt Britton. When he ran
the Review Section (new books), he asked hundreds of
writers who dropped by, many of them major figures in
the American literary world, to draw pictures of themselves. I never met any of these illustrious men of letters
while I was working, but perhaps I just didn't recognize
them from their drrawings.
In a word, the Strand was charming. It appealed
to all of my vague, romantic feelings about what
Greenwich Village was supposed to b( It was also the
only summer job to be found in the city.

Jay Gridders Offto Slow Start Against Division Champs
BY A.J. JOHNSON
The Blue Jay football
season got off to a rocky start
last Saturday as the division
champion Widener Pioneers
defeated Johns Hopkins 48-7.
A combination of powerful
Pioneer running and well-executed fakes and hand-offs
helped Widener to penetrate
the Jay defense repeatedly,
while Hopkins ball carriers
could hardly break through the
Widener line. Hopkins, unable
to coordinate its passing
attempts for most of the game,
relied heavily on a running
attack which proved unsuccessful against the Pioneers.

Hal Johnson of Widener
scored a touchdown on the
first Pioneer possession of the
game wiien he cruised through
a hole in the Hopkins line. On
the next Hopkins possession,
Bruce Kane fumbled the ball
on the Hopkins 25-yard line,
and Widener recovered,scoring
the second Pioneer touchdown
a few plays later.
Hopkins quarterback Jim
Margraff was usually unable to
complete passes to either Bill
Stromberg or wide receiver
John Potthast. In the secon
quarter, a toss intended for
Stromberg was intercepted by
Widener safety Tom Deary,
setting the stage for the third

Pioneer touchdown. A long
drive downfield later in the
second quarter gave Widener its
fourth
touchdown.
At
halftime, the score stood at
28-0 in favor of the Pioneers.
After the half, the Jays
attacked with more force. A
drive early in the third quarter
put them in scoring position
until a clipping penalty killed
the opportunity. Hopkins had
to punt again, and Widener
scored another touchdown on
the possession. The Pioneers
then got in another punch as
Hal Johnson scored his second
goal of the game, raising the
score to 41-0.
In the fourth quarter, the

Jays put their only tally on the
board. Mike Miller intercepted
a Widener pass at the Hopkins
41-yard line and the Jays
moved the ball downfield. Jim
Margraff, injured in the third
quarter, was replaced by
freshman quarterback John
Bevilacqua, who gave an impressive debut performance.
Bevilacqua completed passes to
both Stromberg and tight end
Randy Scholl for the only
fruitful Jay attack.
The
Hopkins touchdown was scored on a pass caught by
Potthast.
The Jays threatened again
in the final minutes of the
fourth quarter, bringing the

ball to a first-and-goal with
fifteen seconds remaining in
the game. Widener held tight,
though, and Hopkins was prevented from scoring as the
clock ran out.
Despite their lackluster
performance against the Pioneers, the Jays could not count
the game as a total loss.
Widener dominates Division Ill
football play year after year,
almost the same way Hopkins
dominates in Lacrosse. While
starting out the season against
the toughest opponent may be
demoralizing, it also helps
point out early season mistakes
in time to correct them.
